central_thesis: The book presents a comprehensive system of Qabalistic philosophy and practical magic, integrating traditional Hermetic Golden Dawn teachings, Tarot symbolism, and specific invocations with Steven Ashe's unique 'Qabalah of Fifty Gates' for psychological and spiritual self-development, culminating in the attainment of spiritual awakening and self-knowledge through structured experiential work.

structure_content.summary: This section introduces the author's background and engagement with Qabalah since 1979, and places the work within the context of the Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn. It discusses the concept of divine consciousness, the evolution of esoteric systems with scientific and psychological advancements, and introduces J.G. Bennett's 'Orders of Being' (Psycho-Static, Psycho-Kinetic, Psycho-Telios) as a framework for spiritual progress.

structure_content.chapter_title: A General Introduction to the Qabalah
structure_content.summary: This part explains the Qabalistic Tree of Life, its ten Sephiroth (emanations), and twenty-two connecting paths, detailing their symbolic meanings and order of descent. It introduces the concept of creation as an overspill of divine impulse, the relationship between human perception and the universe ('As Above - So Below'), and briefly touches upon Hebrew letters and numerology.

This section delves into the historical origins of Qabalah, tracing its tradition as an oral doctrine communicated to Adam by Archangel Ratziel and later committed to writing. It discusses key Qabalistic texts like the Sepher Yetzirah (Book of Formation) and Sepher Zohar (Book of Splendour), their authorship, influence from Judaic Merkabah mysticism, and the evolution of Qabalistic thought.

This chapter explores the distinct Sufi-oriented semantic system of 'Cabala' and its historical ties to Spanish Qabalah and Arabic wisdom. It discusses how these influences contributed to the Rosicrucian tradition and the intellectual climate of the Renaissance, citing figures like Michael Scott as potential catalysts.

Steven Ashe presents his unique system of 'Fifty Gates,' which are described as states of mind generated by the experience of the Sephiroth and Paths. This system challenges traditional interpretations of 'Four Hundred Desirable Worlds' and emphasizes an experiential journey of self-realization and empowerment through 'Overself cross-wiring' techniques, connecting the microcosm to the Macrocosm.

This extensive section analyzes the historical and symbolic evolution of Tarot trumps, acknowledging their origins in medieval Europe and subsequent influences from ancient Egyptian and Middle-Eastern motifs. It provides divinatory meanings for numerous major arcana cards, linking their iconography to cultural, religious, and mythological contexts, and discusses their use in fortune-telling and esoteric study.

This chapter details the philosophy and practical mechanics of invocation, drawing heavily from Eliphas Levi and Aleister Crowley. It explains how invocations stimulate imaginative faculties and connect human will with divine will. The text outlines planetary associations (Saturn, Jupiter, Mars, Sun, Venus, Mercury, Moon) and provides guidance on structuring rites to attune the practitioner to specific divine energies.

structure_content.chapter_title: Rites & Rituals of the Fraternity of the Sanctum Regnum
structure_content.summary: This practical section provides specific instructions for rituals, including the Lesser Ritual of the Pentagram, the Qabalistic Cross, the Grand Qabalistic Invocation, and the Consecration of Water, Salt & Ash. It also includes the full text for Planetary and Zodiacal Invocations, serving as a manual for active practitioners.

structure_content.chapter_title: Shemhamphorash: The Magical System of the 72 Fold Name
structure_content.summary: This part elaborates on the 72-fold name of God, its projection onto the Zodiac, and its application in identifying Guardian Angels corresponding to three aspects of an individual's Being (Animal Soul, Personality, Higher Soul) based on birth chart positions of the Moon, Mercury, and Sun. It explains how these Angels can be invoked using Psalms and employed in talismanic magic.

Translated from historical texts, this section provides detailed descriptions and meanings for each of the thirty-two paths connecting the Sephiroth on the Tree of Life. Each path is given a specific 'Intelligence' name (e.g., Admirable, Illuminating, Sanctifying) and a brief definition of its qabalistic significance.

structure_content.chapter_title: Appendices - An Introduction to the Study of the Kabalah By William Wynn Westcott
structure_content.summary: This appendix, authored by William Wynn Westcott, offers a scholarly and historical overview of Kabalah, discussing its origins, major texts (Sepher Yetzirah, Zohar), and various schools of thought. It differentiates between Dogmatic (Theoretical) and Practical Kabalah, explaining methods like Gematria, Notaricon, and Temura, and elaborating on Kabalistic cosmology, the nature of God, the human soul, and reincarnation, with a focus on its philosophical depth and esoteric interpretations.

key_concepts.definition: A verbal tradition of secret religious lore, literally translating from Hebrew as 'from mouth to ear', pertaining to the divine creative impulse and its manifestations.
The ten divine emanations or spheres upon the Tree of Life, representing products of the overflow of the original act of Creation, embodying alternating stages of force and form.

A Qabalistic glyph composed of ten Sephiroth and twenty-two connecting paths, considered a living entity whose roots extend beyond dimensional reality, mapping human emotions and motivations to divine origins.

A system proposed by Steven Ashe, comprising states of mind generated by the experience of the Sephiroth and the twenty-two Paths, separating the noumenal world from the Supernal Triad and facilitating self-realization through inner exploration.

The seventy-two fold name of God, projected around the Zodiac in seventy-two units. It reveals Guardian Angels governing the Animal Soul (Nephesch), Personality (Ruach), and Higher Soul (Neschamah) based on birth chart positions, used for invocation and talismanic magic.

The sacred Chariot of Ezekiel, symbolizing the 'Throne in its position in Heaven'. It represents a Qabalistic technique for astral projection ('Rising on the Planes') where the astral form makes contact with Macrocosmic powers, accessed through the twelve gates of the Holy City Jerusalem.

Four realms of manifestation in the manifest universe: Atziluth (Archetypes), Briah (Creativity), Yetzirah (Formation), and Assiah (Activity), representing successive stages of divine emanation and condensation.
A state of perfection and exaltation evidenced within the awakened Self, representing the ultimate goal for aspirants seeking spiritual awakening in J.G. Bennett's system.
A mode of interpretation where a word's numerical value is deemed to relate to other words with the same value, used to uncover concealed meanings in sacred texts.

An abbreviation technique where one word is formed from the initial or final letters of multiple words, or letters of one name are taken as initials/finals of words in a sentence, revealing hidden meanings.
A complex permutation method involving transposing or replacing letters in a word according to specific rules or diagrams to derive new meanings or forms for divination.

The art of stimulating the imaginative faculties through spoken, poetic orations, focused in theme and content, to attain states of revelation and connect human will with divine will, often tailored to specific planetary harmonics.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined in 'Qabalah - The Necoris Codex' is an integrative framework designed for spiritual self-development and the operative harnessing of divine energies. It combines classical Hermetic Qabalah (Tree of Life, Sephiroth, 32 Paths) with Golden Dawn ritual practices, detailed Tarot symbolism, and planetary/zodiacal invocations. A central operative component is Steven Ashe's 'Qabalah of Fifty Gates,' an experiential system for navigating states of mind derived from the Sephiroth and Paths to achieve self-realization. The Shemhamphorash provides a method for identifying and invoking specific angelic forces (Guardian Angels) tailored to an individual's birth chart, emphasizing balancing and enhancing physical, personal, and spiritual aspects of being. The system stresses disciplined effort, attunement, and conscious engagement with symbolic metaphors to achieve 'Psycho-Telios' (perfection of the Self).

relevant_quotes.text: Steven Ashe was born in 1960, lives in Glastonbury, England and has been actively involved in the literary and practical Qabalah since 1979.
Title: Qabalah - The Necoris Codex Author: Steven Ashe Category: Religion & Spirituality Publisher: Vondel Park 2006 Edition: First Edition

The approach of seekers pursuing the formula of attainment popularised by the Hermetic Order Of the Golden Dawn (G.D.) is based upon the notion of a hierarchical manifestation of consciousness prevalent throughout the Cosmos.

His first published full length work upon advanced Qabalistic lore 'Qabalah of 50 Gates' (Mandrake of Oxford 2002) is considered to be one of the most exciting experimental works of Qabalistic philosophy in the English language.

The Qabalistic Tree of Life glyph is composed of ten Sephiroth, twenty two Paths (which are in effect the combined influences of the Sephiroth) and 50 Gates which constitute states of mind generated by our experience of the Sephiroth and the twenty two Paths.

In the mystery tradition of the Rosicrucian Qabalah, individuals who have successfully developed their inner nature to a measure of perfection are believed to reincarnate as members of that elect body of evolved masters who constitute the angelic host known as the Ishim, or perfected ones. This is metaphorical of the path of attainment.

Touching the left shoulder, say ve-Gedulah. Clasping the hands upon the breast1, say le-Olahm. Amen. The Rite of the Pentagram Turning to the East, make a pentagram (that of Earth - drawing first from top to bottom left point). say: IHVH (pronounced: "Yah-Ho-Vau-H").

"The danger of ceremonial 'magick' --- the subtlest and deepest danger --- is this: that the magician will naturally tend to invoke that partial being which most strongly appeals to him, so that his natural excess in that direction will be still further exaggerated. Let him, before beginning his Work, endeavour to map out his own being, and arrange his invocations in such a way as to redress the balance."

The System of the Fifty Gates explored in the present work, when laid alongside the more traditionally accepted systems of path working, unites the mysteries of the numbers and the letters of the Sepher Yetzirah.

critical_analysis.relevance: Steven Ashe's 'Qabalah - The Necoris Codex' serves as a highly relevant and comprehensive guide within Western Esotericism, particularly for practitioners of Qabalah and Hermetic magic. It meticulously details foundational concepts, historical evolution, and practical applications, offering both theoretical depth and operative instructions. The introduction of the 'Fifty Gates' system provides a unique framework for psychological and spiritual self-development, aiming to bridge traditional Qabalistic structures with a more experiential and modern approach to consciousness and self-realization. By integrating Tarot, planetary invocations, and the Shemhamphorash with a clear path for inner work, the book solidifies its position as a significant resource for magicians seeking systematic personal transformation and understanding of divine forces.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience includes serious students and practitioners of Western Esotericism, Hermetic Qabalah, and ceremonial magic. It caters to individuals interested in the Golden Dawn tradition, Rosicrucian philosophy, and those seeking detailed, structured methods for spiritual self-development and the practical application of magical theory. The blend of historical context, philosophical depth, and explicit ritual instructions makes it suitable for both dedicated beginners and more advanced adepts within occult traditions.
